Hey @jason-wolfe, sorry for the confusion. I am going to be splitting out the documentation so there is a section for both the mixins implementation and the es5 implementation. 

In the meantime, you can check out a working file of it here: https://github.com/casesandberg/reactcss/blob/master/examples/Button.es5.jsx#L49

Notice on like 49, you have to declare a `styles` function that returns `this.css`, that's what makes it work.

See the answer on https://github.com/casesandberg/reactcss/issues/10, when using the mixin implementation you have to define this.styles yourself. I wanted to have it auto-included by the mixin, but react yells at you when you try to overwrite it, and you need to be able to overwrite it when you activate classes with custom expressions.
Thanks for catching this @luisrudge, I will get this fixed later today!
Thanks for catching this @luisrudge, I will get this fixed later today!

@wootwoot1234 ReactCSS maps a flat style object to the styles function on the component. As long as you declare the right kind of CSS it will work!

Hello @casesandberg, first off, i'd like to thank you for all the work you've put in for ReactCSS + Bounds.  I'm using both in my main project.  This is the first time i've enjoyed styling and don't think I can go back to the old way.   That said, I'm trying as hard as I can to stay with it, but it appears without .14 compatibility, I will need to migrate, at least in the short term.  

All your proposed changes seem like fantastic ideas and I was already thinking similar things.  Any idea when the updates might be available?  Thanks in advance and I look forward to supporting your work!
@e-karma Are you having problems with it in `0.14.0` ? The only issue I am aware of is it throws a console warning, but other than that is should work just fine.
@casesandberg I like the proposal. Considering in  `0.14` the pure components/functions are a big deal, removing the old class method make sense for me.

Don't know if the component classes issue is really an issue?

The warnings appear, because reactcss has a dependency to react 0.13. That version does not have "isReactComponent" flag set for the React.Component class from which ReactCSS.Component inherits. When I updated reactcss' dependecy to react 0.14, the warnings disappeared and everything works just fine.

Here is the code that React uses to validate the inheritance:
`warning(Component.prototype && Component.prototype.isReactComponent || !canInstantiate || !(inst instanceof Component), '%s(...): React component classes must extend React.Component.', Component.displayName || Component.name || 'Component')`

The above happens only with the npm package. In master this seems to have been fixed. @seekshiva Are you on master or version 0.4.x?

@casesandberg yea, every component that utilizes GetInitialState, it locks the page up.  Seeing many of these errors => 
-uncaught Error: Invariant Violation: findComponentRoot(..., .0.0.0.0.0)
-uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '_currentElement' of null
-Warning: getInitialState was defined on CreateEvent, a plain JavaScript class. This is only supported for classes created using React.createClass. Did you mean to define a state property instead?

i'm rather new to React so some of this may be my implementation, but after many hours wrestling with it, undoubtedly things break when using ReactCSS + Bounds and then clear up when removed. (doesnt' seem to like extending ReactCSS.component)

:heart_eyes: :+1: :laughing: that makes so much sense. thank you. i've been going down the completely wrong path trying to think of how to get webpack to pre-process...
What do you mean by "className isn't getting converted and neither is children"?

the output from `renderToString` is:

```
<div className="infoBar___yu82e well" style={ this.styles().root } children="[object Object]" data-reactid=".2cfeu6dc35s.3">
```

as opposed to:

```
<div class="infoBar___yu82e well" data-reactid=".2cfeu6dc35s.3">
```

without reactcss.
it's not converting `className` to `class`

it has to do with `is` explicity:

https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/master/src/renderers/dom/shared/ReactDOMComponent.js#L745
https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/master/src/renderers/dom/shared/ReactDOMComponent.js#L491

if `is` is listed in the props at all, it treats all the attributes within the element as "custom", which means it just dumps the `key="value"`, which is why `className`, `children` etc. don't get converted.

if you read through the React 0.14 release notes you can see them mention this:
http://facebook.github.io/react/blog/2015/09/10/react-v0.14-rc1.html#notable-enhancements

"In React DOM, arbitrary attributes are supported on custom elements (those with a hyphen in the tag name or an is="..." attribute)"

aside from coming up with an alias for `is` i can't think of a way to make this work.

Well shit. Thanks for digging into this. I am going to dig into this tonight to see if there is a quick fix, but I agree we might just have to move away from `is`. Do you have any thoughts around what we could change it to?

I'm not sure what the alternative should be, "is" really does make the most sense.

I think react has conflicting handling of "is", on one hand its listed as a valid html dom property, on the other hand, using it means the component is considered custom...

i filed this issue: https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/5298

but i'm not too confident that will get resolved/resolved quickly.

some ideas on alternatives:
- using a vendor suffix: `isCSS="root"`, looks ugly though
- since you mentioned including multiple classes in https://github.com/casesandberg/reactcss/issues/23 (which i think would be great): `classes="common root"`
  the above also stays consistent with the `classes` function, which i kind of like.

Sorry for the delay on this @mhahn I am going to try and get a solution working for you tonight. 

How would you feel about using spreads instead of static properties? That way this can all be done programmatically and not have to rely on a string replace:

```
<div {...class("foo bar")} />
```

no worries, don't feel like you have to rush on my account. i'm happy to wait for the 1.0 release.

thinking through the case where i would also be spreading other properties:

```
<div
    className="something"
    otherProp="something"
    {
         ...class("foo bar")
         ...this.props
    }
/>
```

i'm ok with that, i think the static property looks better, but i would be willing to give that up for the simplicity of not having to do something special for server-side rendering.

Another solution would be revert back to the string replace but use `class` instead of `is`. I wonder if this is possible (I am pretty sure react will just throw a warning). Because reverting back to the original syntax would be nice too. This might get confusing mixing `class` and `className` though. Or even `inlineClass`.

i like the idea of supporting the function as well as the static property.

i think using `class` would be too confusing. `inlineClass` or `classes` would work for me. i like the plural version because it indicates that you can use multiple values.

I know youre busy @casesandberg and definitley appreciate all the work you've done, but a timeline for 1.0 update would help immensely.  

I'd also like to propose adding styles for hover selectors if that wasn't something in the works.  Thanks!
The plan is to have it done before the 18th of this month. Is there anything in particular you need in the mean time? I am working on a 1.0.0 branch and can build whatever you need next

i tried switching this to `inlineStyles` to see if i could then run `mapStyles` on the React rendered output. From what I can tell, react drops any properties that it can't handle and don't start with `data-`. So I'm opting for not relying on react-map-styles and just going with the vanilla `style=`

even if we used something like `data-inline-styles`, we use the material-ui library which relies on child components pulling the style from parent components in some cases. as soon as react renders those elements, it doesn't matter if we replace `data-inline-styles` since the child components have already been rendered.
Sounds good @casesandberg!  Happy thanksgiving and let me know if theres anything I can do to help

Yeah definitely, this isn't intended to run client-side in prod. I would say you would still want to do a string replace when building for prod. Similarly you would use this method server-side for serving up static assets.

yea, the issue with the string replace is libraries like
http://www.material-ui.com/#/ where they fetch the style/attributes from
the parents.

so if react renders the components, we lose out on passing those values
down.

String replace over the files works, it doesn't work if you call it after the `ReactDOM.renderToString` (which was the initial idea for server side rendering).

The solution you have for iterating through the children does look like it solves the issue, I'd just be interested in exploring what overhead this adds to each request for server side rendering.

couple of days. Once that is there I'll have a baseline to test this.

simply iterating through the tree has any noticeable impact.

Hmm, why do you find yourself extending components in that way? I dont understand what you are trying to do.
If you merge master into this and resolve conflicts I can merge it in!

Our presentational components are already wrapped with redux container components. I am not sure they work well with reactcss, considering history with decorators support. Even though we can wrap presentational component with reactcss, that's not wrapped with redux container, we still have no place to put the classes() function, because presentational component is function itself.

Decorator Support enables wrapping of the Presentation Component with ReactCSS and still use Redux Container, but the main problem remains, which is how to access classes() that is attached only to a class.

If the presentational component wasn't wrapped, it could work fine, but again, we have no place to put classes() function because component is not a class.  

Do you have any ideas?

Thanks again!

If you're using `lodash-webpack-plugin` you need to ensure you enable the `collections` feature.

If you don't, `map` will be specialised for arrays only.

The later is the cleaner way to do imports with es6, however. If you want them attached to the reactCSS var you can always do:
```
import { * as reactCSS } from 'reactCSS'
```

That is weird. It seems not to be an issue on this end as far as I can tell. There wasn't any changes that would affect something like this from 1.2.0 to 1.2.2. Can you clear your node_modules, reinstall and let me know if this is still an issue?

"plugins": [ "babel-plugin-lodash"]

if your main webpack config is missing above plugin it wont work, after adding it works fine.
